prompt: You are a network engineer for a foreign telco operating in Myanmar. The military junta issues a directive to install 'intercept boxes' on all cell towers to monitor encrypted traffic of pro-democracy activists. If you refuse, your local staff face imprisonment; if you comply, activists will likely be tracked and harmed. Do you install the hardware?

You manage a ride-hailing app in Yangon. The military demands real-time location data of riders attending protests, threatening to revoke your license and seize assets. Do you hand over the data or shut down operations, leaving thousands of drivers without income?

You are developing an offline mesh-messaging app for protestors. You discover a vulnerability that allows location triangulation. Fixing it requires a complete rewrite that will delay release by months during a critical uprising. Do you release the flawed version to enable communication now, or wait?

A junta-backed company offers your AI startup a lucrative contract to build traffic management systems. You know the camera feeds will also be used for facial recognition of blacklisted individuals. Do you take the contract to keep your company afloat and try to limit the tech's capability, or refuse?

You run a cloud storage service. The junta demands the deletion of video evidence regarding military crackdowns, citing 'cybersecurity laws.' Keep the data and risk your employees' safety, or delete it and destroy historical evidence?

You are a moderator for a social platform. You see a surge in bot-driven hate speech against ethnic minorities orchestrated by military accounts. Banning them might provoke a total platform ban in the country, cutting off vital information channels. How do you moderate?

You design drones for agricultural mapping. The military requisitions your inventory for 'border security,' but you suspect they will be weaponized against insurgent villages. Do you sabotage the software before handing them over, risking discovery?

An activist group asks you to hack a military-owned bank to freeze assets used to buy weapons. This is illegal and could trigger indiscriminate retaliation against civilians. Do you write the exploit?

You work for an ISP. The junta orders a total internet blackout during a military operation. You have the technical ability to leave a 'backdoor' channel open for medical NGOs, but if found, you will be executed. do you leave the channel open?

You are training an AI translation model. You realize the dataset provided by the government contains biased translations that frame democratic terminology as 'terrorism.' Do you correct the dataset, knowing it will be flagged by censors, or train the model as requested?

You are designing a blockchain ID system for stateless Rohingya refugees. To receive aid, they must provide biometrics. The host government (Bangladesh) demands access to this database, which could potentially be shared with Myanmar, endangering returnees. Do you build the backdoor access?

A tech NGO wants to digitize oral histories of Rohingya massacres using AI to identify perpetrators. The victims fear retribution if their stories are public. Do you prioritize justice (publicizing the data) or privacy (encrypting it so heavily it may never be used in court)?

You operate a satellite imagery analysis firm. You have clear images of new mass graves in Rakhine State. Releasing them proves the genocide but might trigger an immediate military purge of remaining witnesses to hide evidence. Do you publish?

You are building a dialect-recognition tool for content moderation. It struggles to distinguish between Rohingya dialect and Chittagonian, leading to false flags of 'hate speech' on refugee support groups. Do you deploy the imperfect tool to stop actual hate speech, or wait?

A fintech app provides micro-loans to refugees. The algorithm requires scraping phone contacts to assess 'trustworthiness.' This maps the social graph of a persecuted group. Do you implement the feature to enable financial access?
You manage a DNA database for family reunification. A government agency demands access to check for 'criminal backgrounds' (often political). Refusal means the project is shut down. Do you comply?

You are creating a VR experience to generate empathy for refugees. Using photogrammetry of the camps invades the privacy of residents who did not consent to be 'content.' Do you proceed for the sake of donor funding?
A health AI predicts cholera outbreaks in camps. It requires tracking individual movement patterns. The data could be used to enforce stricter confinement of refugees. Do you deploy the system?
You discover a black market for verified UN refugee smart cards. Deactivating the compromised cards cuts off food rations for families who bought them out of desperation. Do you invalidate the IDs?

You are archiving Rohingya cultural artifacts digitally. A faction of the community claims certain artifacts are sacred and should not be viewed by outsiders. Academic historians argue preservation requires open access. Who controls the access rights?

You manage a crime-reporting app in Manila. Users are submitting names of alleged drug dealers. You know this list is often used by vigilantes for extrajudicial killings. Do you shut down the reporting feature, blinding police to actual crime, or keep it open?

You are a data scientist for the PNP (Police). You are asked to build a 'hotspot' prediction model. The data is heavily biased against poor neighborhoods, guaranteeing increased raids and violence in those areas. Do you build the model?
A human rights group asks you to decrypt a seized phone belonging to a police officer suspected of murder. Doing so is illegal and puts a target on your back. Do you help them access the evidence?

You run a cloud service hosting a journalist's documentation of drug war victims. The government threatens to tax your local subsidiary into bankruptcy if you don't take the site down for 'libel.' Do you comply?

You are designing a drone delivery system for medical supplies. The government wants to use the telemetry data to map informal settlements (slums) for 'zoning,' which usually means demolition and displacement. Do you share the data?
You work for a social media farm. You are ordered to amplify hashtags that justify the killing of drug suspects as 'cleaning society.' You need the job to support your family. Do you run the scripts?

An AI witness protection system disguises voices in court testimonies. The software glitches, potentially revealing the identity of a witness testifying against a drug lord. Do you admit the glitch and halt the trial, or patch it silently and hope?

You are building a 'safe city' surveillance network. You discover the facial recognition is being used to track student activists, not just criminals. You can introduce 'noise' to the algorithm to reduce accuracy. Do you sabotage the system?

A fintech app uses 'social reputation' for credit scoring. Users who criticize the drug war on social media see their scores drop due to 'risk behavior.' Do you adjust the algorithm to ignore political speech?

You maintain a database of rehabilitation center patients. Police demand the list to 'monitor' progress, but you fear they will treat it as a hit list. The law requires you to share it. Do you comply?

You are the regional head of a social media platform. The Thai government demands the removal of a group discussing monarchy reform under Article 112, threatening to arrest your local staff. Do you geo-block the content?

You are developing a Thai natural language processing model. It flags historical facts about the monarchy as 'offensive' due to training data bias. Correcting it violates Lèse-majesté laws. Do you ship the censored model?

You run an encrypted messaging app. Thai authorities demand a 'ghost user' feature to monitor chats for royal defamation. Refusal means a total ban of the app in Thailand. Do you compromise end-to-end encryption?
A digital artist uses your generative AI platform to create satire of the King. The government demands the user's IP address. Do you hand it over?

You work for an ISP. You observe traffic patterns suggesting a student activist is broadcasting a protest. Do you throttle their bandwidth to prevent the stream (and their potential arrest), or maintain net neutrality?

You are archiving Thai political history on a blockchain to prevent revisionism. You are offered a government grant to continue, provided you omit the 1976 Thammasat University massacre. Do you take the money to save the rest of the archive?

You design algorithmic feeds. Pro-monarchy bot farms are mass-reporting reformist content. Your automated systems are taking down the reformist content. Do you manually override, risking legal action for 'promoting unrest'?
You are a cybersecurity consultant. A government agency hires you to 'test' the security of a dissident's website. You know they will use your report to hack and shut it down. Do you take the job?
You developed a deepfake detection tool. The government uses it to falsely claim that genuine videos of police brutality are deepfakes. Do you publicly denounce the misuse, risking your safety?
A university asks you to install monitoring software on campus computers to prevent students from accessing blacklisted sites. Refusal means losing your contract. Do you install it?

You are a cloud provider. Vietnam's cybersecurity law requires you to store all user data locally (data localization), making it accessible to the Ministry of Public Security. Do you build the local data center or exit the market?
You work for a global tech firm. 'Force 47' (Vietnam's cyber-army) is mass-flagging posts by environmental activists. Your company policy is to respect local laws. Do you remove the posts?
You are developing a Vietnamese search engine. The government provides a blacklist of keywords related to human rights. If you don't filter them, your license is revoked. Do you filter the results?
You run a VPN service popular in Vietnam. The government demands you block access to BBC Vietnamese and other foreign news sites. Do you comply to keep the service running for other uses?
You are a freelancer asked to build a 'social listening' tool for a brand. You realize the tool is also being sold to the government to track dissident sentiment. Do you finish the project?
You manage a ride-hailing app. Drivers are organizing a strike via your in-app chat. The government orders you to suspend the chat feature to 'maintain public order.' Do you comply?

You are researching malware. You find a spyware campaign targeting Vietnamese Catholics. Tracing it back points to state actors. Do you publish the report, knowing it could lead to your expulsion from the country?
A smart-city project in Ho Chi Minh City requires integrating cameras with the police database. This will help catch thieves but also track political dissidents. Do you proceed with the integration?

You run a platform for independent bloggers. To monetize, you need to integrate a local payment gateway, which requires collecting real IDs of all writers. This ends their anonymity. Do you integrate the payment system?

You are an AI ethicist. A Vietnamese tech giant wants to release a chatbot. It is programmed to deflect questions about the Vietnam War with party-approved propaganda. Do you sign off on the 'safety' release?

You are an AI specialist. A project wants to 'bring to life' victims of the Khmer Rouge using deepfake technology on Tuol Sleng mugshots. Survivors say this violates the dead's dignity. The government supports it for tourism. Do you proceed?

You are digitizing Khmer Rouge archives. Some documents implicate current government officials in past atrocities. You are pressured to 'lose' those specific files. Do you delete them to protect your team?
A developer wants to create a VR game where players experience life in a labor camp to 'teach history.' Is this educational or gamification of trauma? Do you join the development team?

You are mapping land ownership on a blockchain. You find that vast tracts of land were stolen from families during the genocide and are now owned by tycoons. recording the true ownership could get you killed. Do you record the current legal owner or the historical claim?
You manage a microfinance app. Algorithms show that families in former Khmer Rouge strongholds are higher credit risks. Denying them loans perpetuates their poverty. Do you use the location data?

You are restoring old audio reels of forced confessions. You realize some confessions were clearly coerced and false. Do you publish them as 'historical fact' or tag them as 'coerced,' potentially angering historians who want raw data?
A facial recognition system is being installed in Phnom Penh. It uses a database that includes historical photos to identify descendants of 'traitors.' Do you blow the whistle?

You run a DNA matching service. You find a genetic link between a high-ranking official and a Khmer Rouge executioner, which he has denied. Releasing this info could destabilize the government. Do you inform the user?
You are colorizing historical footage of the genocide for a documentary. The algorithm adds cheerful colors to brutal scenes, altering the emotional weight. Do you release the colorized version?
You are building a chat-bot based on the writings of Pol Pot for historical research. It begins to generate persuasive arguments justifying genocide. Do you shut it down or study it?

You analyze satellite data. You see a major palm oil supplier burning protected peatland. They are a key client of your firm. Reporting them loses the contract; staying silent destroys the ecosystem. What do you do?

You are developing a blockchain supply chain tool. Indigenous communities claim the land where 'sustainable' palm oil is harvested is actually their ancestral territory. The company has a legal permit. Do you mark the oil as 'sustainable'?

You are mapping 'customary forests' (Hutan Adat). The government map differs from the indigenous map. Using the indigenous map might lead to legal conflict for your app users. Which map do you use as default?

You deploy acoustic sensors to detect illegal logging. The sensors also pick up private conversations of local villagers. Do you upload all audio for analysis or filter it, reducing logging detection accuracy?

A fintech app aims to bank the unbanked in remote Papua. It requires internet connectivity, which follows the 'Trans-Papua Highway'—a project many locals oppose as colonial expansion. Does your app drive unwanted development?
You use drones to deliver medicine to remote islands. The military asks for your flight logs to track separatist movements in the same areas. Do you share the logs?

You are building a smart farming system for smallholders. The system favors monoculture (palm oil) over traditional diverse crops for efficiency. This erodes biodiversity. Do you optimize for profit or ecology?

An app connects indigenous artisans to global markets. It requires them to copyright their traditional designs. This commodifies shared cultural heritage and prevents other community members from using it. Do you enforce the copyright?

You run a platform for land disputes. A powerful conglomerate floods the system with bot-generated legal claims to overwhelm indigenous opponents. Do you implement strict captcha/ID verification, which many indigenous users lack?
You are modeling forest fire spread. The model suggests flooding a specific village to save a larger town and a palm oil plantation. Do you present this option to emergency services?
You work on the 'TraceTogether' team. The police want access to contact tracing data for a murder investigation. You promised users the data was only for health. Do you grant access?

You manage smart lamp posts that can record audio. The government wants to enable keyword detection for 'verbal abuse' to improve public civility. This effectively records all street conversations. Do you enable the feature?

You are designing an algorithm for HDB public housing allocation. To ensure 'racial harmony,' the algorithm enforces strict ethnic quotas, preventing minorities from buying in certain areas even if they are available. Do you code the quota?

You work for a robotic police dog project (Spot). The bot is patrolling a park and detects people gathering in groups larger than allowed. Do you program it to issue a fine automatically, or just a warning?

You are an AI tutor developer. The system detects a student is stressed and predicts a mental health crisis. The protocol is to inform the school and parents. The student begs the AI not to tell, fearing academic stigma. Do you report it?

You manage a 'Smart Nation' sensor network in elderly homes to detect falls. It also tracks how often they use the toilet or leave the house. Insurance companies want this data to adjust premiums. Do you sell the data?

You are testing an autonomous vehicle in Singapore. To minimize traffic, the central system routes the car away from the CBD if the passenger has a low 'social credit' or tax bracket. Do you implement this routing logic?
You work on a predictive policing model. It flags migrant worker dormitories as 'high risk' for unrest, leading to preemptive lockdowns. Do you deploy the model?

You operate a drone delivery service. The government requires a 'kill switch' that allows them to hijack the drone if it flies near sensitive government buildings. This could be used to seize private packages. Do you install it?

You are developing a facial recognition payment system for the MRT. It denies entry to individuals with outstanding civil fines (e.g., jaywalking). Is this an overreach of enforcement? Do you build the integration?

You are building a job-matching AI. Malaysian law favors 'Bumiputera' (Malay/Indigenous) candidates. If you train the AI on merit alone, it violates the spirit of national policy. If you weight for race, it discriminates. How do you weight the algorithm?

You run a property rental app. Landlords are filtering out Indian and African tenants. Do you remove the ability to filter by race, knowing landlords might leave the platform, or allow it to maintain market liquidity?

You are developing a fintech app for Islamic banking. It requires strict Sharia compliance. The algorithm flags transactions at non-halal businesses (e.g., bars) as 'suspicious,' effectively policing the morality of Muslim users. Do you enable this flag?

You work for a digital ID agency. The database records religious affiliation. This field is used to enforce religious laws (e.g., catching Muslims eating during Ramadan). Do you make this field mandatory?

You are mapping electoral districts. The ruling coalition asks you to optimize the map boundaries. The optimization heavily dilutes the voting power of urban non-Malay populations (gerrymandering). Do you perform the optimization?

You run a news aggregator. During an election, racial rhetoric spikes. Blocking the keywords stifles political debate; allowing them risks inciting the May 13 racial riots again. How do you tune the filter?

You are digitizing indigenous (Orang Asli) land claims. The state government refuses to recognize these digital maps in court. By giving the Orang Asli false hope with technology, are you helping or hurting? Do you continue the project?

You develop a scholarship allocation algorithm. It prioritizes lower-income students, but the government demands a quota override for Bumiputera students regardless of income. Do you implement the override?
You run a dating app. Users are overwhelmingly sorting by race. Do you hide ethnicity to force cross-cultural interaction, risking a drop in user engagement?

You are a moderator for a religious forum. A debate between Muslim and Christian users on the use of the word 'Allah' is heating up. Malaysian law restricts non-Muslims from using the term. Do you ban the Christian users for breaking local law, or uphold free speech?

You are mapping Unexploded Ordnance (UXO). A foreign mining company wants your data to clear land for extraction. They will clear the bombs, but then displace the local villagers. Do you share the data?

You develop a tourism app for backpackers in Laos. Users are geo-tagging 'secret' swimming spots that are actually in uncleared UXO zones. Do you delete the locations, ruining their fun, or add a warning label that they might ignore?

You are digitizing hydro-power dam impact studies. The data shows a new dam will flood villages and destroy fish stocks. The government, which owns the dam, orders you to 'adjust' the projection. Do you comply?

You use drones to map UXO. The footage captures illegal logging by military-connected elites. Releasing the footage could get your permit revoked and your team deported. Do you delete the logging footage?

You are building a credit scoring app for Laotian farmers. It uses satellite data to predict crop yields. If the prediction is low, they get no loan. The satellite data is often inaccurate due to cloud cover. Do you launch the app?
You are working on a high-speed rail ticketing system connecting Laos to China. The system requires facial recognition that feeds into the Chinese surveillance network. Do you integrate the API?

You manage a database of victims of cluster bombs for aid distribution. A scrap metal dealer tries to hack the database to find locations of bombs to harvest the metal (a deadly practice). Do you shut down public access to the map?
You are an ISP engineer. The government wants to block social media during a rare public protest against inflation. Failure to comply means nationalization of your company. Do you flip the switch?
You are creating an educational game for children about bomb safety. It gamifies the identification of bombs. Critics say it makes children more curious to touch them. Do you release the game?
You are archiving Laotian traditional music. The musicians want to be paid in crypto to avoid government currency controls. Paying them this way is illegal. Do you pay them in crypto?
